screens.headline: You sold a call for $3. Now it's worth $0.30. What do you do?
screens.text: Most beginners wait until expiration - missing huge opportunities to lock in profits early and redeploy capital. Learn the professional exit strategy that can double your annual returns.

screens.headline: Closing = Buying Back Your Sold Call
screens.text: When you SELL a covered call, you can BUY it back anytime before expiration to 'close' the position. If the option has lost value (decayed toward $0), you can buy it back cheap, keep most of the original premium, and sell a NEW call immediately. This is how pros maximize income.

screens.headline: Think of it like a rental agreement
screens.text: You rent out your car for $500/month. After 1 week, the renter says 'I don't need it anymore, I'll pay you $50 to cancel the rental early.' You accept - you keep $450 profit ($500 - $50 buyout), and now you can rent the car to someone else immediately for another $500. You just made $450 in 1 week instead of $500 in 1 month!

reveal_sections.label: Rental income = Premium you sold call for
Early cancellation = Buying back the call cheap
Renting again = Selling a new covered call

cards.definition: Buying back an option you previously sold to close it
cards.example: Sold call for $3, BTC at $0.30 = $2.70 profit locked in

cards.definition: Common strategy: close when option decays to 50% of value
cards.example: Sold for $2, close when it hits $1 (50% profit captured)

cards.definition: Closing current call and opening new one simultaneously
cards.example: Close Jan $190 call, open Feb $195 call

screens.question: You sold a call for $4.00. A week later it's worth $2.00. Should you close it?
options: Yes - lock in $2 profit and sell a new call
No - wait for it to decay to $0 for full profit
Yes - but only if you're bearish on the stock
It depends on how much time is left
screens.explanation_correct: Smart! With 3+ weeks left, wait longer - you might get closer to $0. With <1 week left, close now - that last $2 won't decay fast enough. The time remaining matters!
screens.explanation_wrong: It depends on TIME REMAINING. If there's 3 weeks left, you might capture more decay. If there's 3 days left, close now and sell a new 30-day call. Time is key!

screens.question: Sold $5 call, now worth $0.40 with 2 days until expiration. Close it or wait?
options: Close now and pay $0.40 to lock in $4.60 profit
Wait 2 days to save the $0.40 and get full $5 profit
Close only if stock is moving against you
Never close - always wait for expiration
screens.explanation_correct: Correct! With only 2 days left, that $0.40 will likely decay to near $0 anyway. Save the commission and let it expire. The $0.40 'savings' isn't worth the hassle. Different story if it was 20 days out!
screens.explanation_wrong: With just 2 days left, you're 'picking up pennies' to close it. That $0.40 will decay to near zero naturally. Wait it out - your time is worth more than $40.

screens.headline: Close vs Wait Calculator
screens.description: See when it makes sense to close early and reopen
teaching_points: Try $0.50 current price: Strong case to close
Try 3 days remaining: Maybe wait it out
Try $3 new premium: Lower opportunity cost

cards.back: Option decayed 70%+ AND >2 weeks remaining. Close, lock profit, sell new call. Example: Sold $5, now $1, with 20 days left.
Less than 3-5 days to expiration OR option still has significant value (>50%). Let time decay work for you.
Many pros close at 50% profit (sold $4, buy back at $2) regardless of time. Simple, effective, proven.

screens.badge_description: You know when to close positions early for maximum efficiency
